paragraphs.name: ffa6
paragraphs.text: You’re the commissioner of an international sport that’s rising in popularity. Your “second conversations” are shoddy officiating (which isn’t unique to the NBA), Draymond Green’s karate kicks, and scheduling issues. Big deal. Want to swap gigs and try your hand at protecting the shield?

paragraphs.name: 2e8b
paragraphs.text: There could also be a form of “rest” where the player participates in the game, but he’s required to play for 25 to 50 percent of his usual minutes workload. That way fans get a taste of seeing their favorite player. It’s a compromise. That means LeBron would’ve been forced to play anywhere from nine to 19 minutes last Saturday against the Clippers.

7ce73e165de9.title: The NFL’s problems are only bigger than the NBA’s problems if you don’t recognize that every…

paragraphs.text: The NFL’s problems are only bigger than the NBA’s problems if you don’t recognize that every superstar in the NBA is a problem or a potential problem. Lebron James can tank his popularity with (and ratings in) Ohio by endorsing a candidate his state didn’t like all that much, Kevin Durant can tank the ratings for the Western Conference finals by…
paragraphs.name: 2cef

virtuals.subtitle: No, the NFL’s issues are tiny when you realize that by embracing “the shield” and reigning in individual athletes, it has inoculated itself…

content.subtitle: No, the NFL’s issues are tiny when you realize that by embracing “the shield” and reigning in individual athletes, it has inoculated itself…

e93134525292.title: Eh, aside from working the schedule to make rest easier, especially before prime-time games, I’m…

paragraphs.text: Eh, aside from working the schedule to make rest easier, especially before prime-time games, I’m not for doing anything. I agree, it kind of sucks when the player you paid to see isn’t playing (I got tickets to see the Celtics-76ers game recently because I wanted to see Joel Embiid — didn’t work out when he got injured). I looked into getting Cavs…

virtuals.subtitle: For the most part, teams have gotten smart about rest and fans, in my opinion, should just deal with getting the short end of the stick…

content.subtitle: For the most part, teams have gotten smart about rest and fans, in my opinion, should just deal with getting the short end of the stick…

436de5c34e70.title: I don’t get the gimmick of writing this as if it came from Goodell and then having it be mostly…

paragraphs.text: I don’t get the gimmick of writing this as if it came from Goodell and then having it be mostly serious commentary. This would have been better as a straight article.
But anyway, I agree with the comment that there isn’t really anything that can really be done about resting, and I’m not sure that there should be. The issue…
paragraphs.name: af88

virtuals.subtitle: But anyway, I agree with the comment that there isn’t really anything that can really be done about resting, and I’m not sure that there…

content.subtitle: But anyway, I agree with the comment that there isn’t really anything that can really be done about resting, and I’m not sure that there…

4d6742092cef.title: But this would impact the all-important STATS.

paragraphs.text: But this would impact the all-important STATS. LeBron isn’t going to play 15 minutes and finish with a 10/3/4 stat line. Same with any of the max player guys with major brands. The league is far too stat-driven. Contracts on and off the court are always (perhaps unfairly) driven by on-court measures.
paragraphs.name: c825

virtuals.subtitle: Also, this letter is about 10 times more competent than anything Goodell has ever written or said. Good stuff.

content.subtitle: Also, this letter is about 10 times more competent than anything Goodell has ever written or said. Good stuff.

paragraphs.text: Um, nobody is against resting. He’s just asking for transparency, because nobody wants to spend $300 dollars to watch Richard Jefferson play when you are being told to expect LBJ and co.
paragraphs.name: bdda

ec79179b77f6.title: It honestly feels like this is all just something for us to talk about as we count the days til the…

paragraphs.text: It honestly feels like this is all just something for us to talk about as we count the days til the playoffs. There’s no real way to regulate rest. As Richard Jefferson said on The Jump yesterday, they can just list a nagging injury and voila, injury rest. And any rules about special protected or prime time games imbalances the best teams’ schedules from bad ones.
paragraphs.name: c30e

ad3df60cb0cc.title: You don’t want teams resting players for big TV games? Then get better schedule-makers.

paragraphs.text: You don’t want teams resting players for big TV games? Then get better schedule-makers.
paragraphs.name: a56c

paragraphs.text: Can anyone really blame the Warriors for resting their big four against the Spurs when it was their eighth game in eight cities in thirteen nights (with travel on all five off days)?
paragraphs.name: 5c44

virtuals.subtitle: Can anyone really blame the Warriors for resting their big four against the Spurs when it was their eighth game in eight cities in thirteen…

content.subtitle: Can anyone really blame the Warriors for resting their big four against the Spurs when it was their eighth game in eight cities in thirteen…

979dcae66821.title: There’s no reasonable way to use injury designation as a means of protecting against these…

paragraphs.text: There’s no reasonable way to use injury designation as a means of protecting against these situations. Teams can and will find a way to skirt those rules, or invent nagging injuries. And a fine by the league does nothing for those most impacted by these decisions, the fans.
paragraphs.name: f1a7

virtuals.subtitle: If the NBA really wants to focus on those most impacted, they would implement a rule that would require teams to compensate fans impacted…

cec6cf5f3bee.title: So where does the PED conversation rank in the NBA?

paragraphs.text: So where does the PED conversation rank in the NBA? Does that fall in the “ignored” conversation category? Or is it, “Hey, did you say PED’s? Did you see that Draymond Green karate kick?!”
paragraphs.name: 4a07

b92d0d571927.title: I think the fix is pretty simple.

paragraphs.text: I think the fix is pretty simple. For national TV games if you rest guys then your coach gets a one game suspension and the team’s cap number drops by $1M. On second occurrence coach gets 2 games and its an additional $2M off the cap. After that the punishment goes to 5 games and $5M per occurrence
paragraphs.name: cdad

fe19a8366c38.title: Teams have data now that shows when guys are most susceptible to get injured, based on minutes…

paragraphs.text: Teams have data now that shows when guys are most susceptible to get injured, based on minutes, usage, time between games, etc. Why would teams risk losing a player to injury just so the NBA can protect its TV deal? I’m siding with the players on this one. Kevin O'Connor
paragraphs.name: 0f18

99a36f626241.title: I’ve been debating this topic with myself (which may be either a good practice or the first signs…

paragraphs.text: I’ve been debating this topic with myself (which may be either a good practice or the first signs of coming unhinged) and while I understand the need for added rest with there appearing to be some science to go along with it… the problem is it’s now become just a thing to do, regardless of whether it aligns with that science or not. The Cavs/Clippers…
